statement:
Split closure can be strictly stronger than the rank-1 Lovász–Newton submodular intersection-cut closure for laminar-rank knapsack constraints: there exist n, a laminar matroid rank function r, an integer b, and a polyhedral relaxation P with X={x∈{0,1}^n: r(x)≤b}⊆P⊆[0,1]^n such that
$$
SC\bigl(P\cap\{r(x)\le b\}\bigr)\subsetneq IN^{(1)}_{\mathrm{sub}}\bigl(P;\{x\mapsto r(x)-b\}\bigr).
$$
proof_markdown:
\begin{proof}
Assume, for contradiction, that for the instance described below the equality
$$
SC\bigl(P\cap\{r(x)\le b\}\bigr)\;=\;IN^{(1)}_{\mathrm{sub}}\bigl(P;\{x\mapsto r(x)-b\}\bigr)
$$
holds.

Fix $n=4$, $P=[0,1]^4$, and let $r$ be the rank function of the uniform matroid $U_{3,4}$ (which is laminar): $r(S)=\min\{|S|,3\}$. Take $b=2$. Define the mixed-integer feasible set
$$
S_0\;:=\;P\cap\{x\in\{0,1\}^4: r(x)\le 2\}\;=\;\{x\in\{0,1\}^4:\ \textstyle\sum_{i=1}^4 x_i\le 2\}.
$$
By the assumption, $SC(S_0)=IN^{(1)}_{\mathrm{sub}}(P;\{r-2\})$. We derive a contradiction by exhibiting a point in the right-hand side but not in the left-hand side.

Step 1 (the $IN^{(1)}_{\mathrm{sub}}$ side). The base polytope of $r$ is $B(r)=\{w\in\mathbb{R}^4: 0\le w_i\le 1,\ \sum_i w_i=3\}$. Using the Lovász extension as a support function, for $x\in[0,1]^4$,
$$
\max_{w\in B(r)}\langle w,x\rangle\;=\;x_{(1)}+x_{(2)}+x_{(3)},
$$
where $x_{(1)}\ge x_{(2)}\ge x_{(3)}\ge x_{(4)}$ are the order statistics. Hence
$$
IN^{(1)}_{\mathrm{sub}}(P;\{r-2\})\;=\;\bigl\{x\in[0,1]^4:\ x_{(1)}+x_{(2)}+x_{(3)}\le 2\bigr\}=:S.
$$

Step 2 (the split-closure side is contained in the convex hull). For any $T\subseteq\mathbb{R}^d$ and any split $(\pi,\beta)$ with halfspaces $H^-:=\{\pi^\top x\le\beta\}$ and $H^+:=\{\pi^\top x\ge\beta+1\}$, we have $(T\cap H^-)\cup(T\cap H^+)\subseteq T$, hence
$$
\operatorname{conv}\bigl((T\cap H^-)\cup(T\cap H^+)\bigr)\subseteq\operatorname{conv}(T).
$$
Intersecting over all splits yields $SC(T)\subseteq\operatorname{conv}(T)$. Applying this to $T=S_0$ gives
$$
SC(S_0)\subseteq\operatorname{conv}(S_0).
$$

Step 3 (compute $\operatorname{conv}(S_0)$). We claim
$$
\operatorname{conv}(S_0)\;=\;\Bigl\{x\in[0,1]^4:\ \textstyle\sum_{i=1}^4 x_i\le 2\Bigr\}=:K.
$$
The inclusion $\operatorname{conv}(S_0)\subseteq K$ is immediate. For the reverse inclusion, let $v$ be a vertex of $K$. If $v$ has at least two fractional coordinates, then for small $\varepsilon>0$ the perturbations $v\pm\varepsilon(e_i-e_j)$ remain in $K$, contradicting extremality. If exactly one coordinate is fractional and $\sum_i v_i<2$, then at most three linearly independent constraints are tight (the bounds on the three integral coordinates), so $v$ is not a vertex. If exactly one coordinate is fractional and $\sum_i v_i=2$, then writing the three integral coordinates’ sum as an integer $k$ gives the fractional coordinate $2-k\in(0,1)$, forcing $k\in(1,2)$, impossible. Hence all coordinates of a vertex are integral and satisfy $\sum_i v_i\le 2$, so $v\in S_0$. Therefore $K\subseteq\operatorname{conv}(S_0)$ and the claim follows.

Step 4 (contradiction). Let $x^*=(0.8,0.8,0.4,0.4)$. Then $x^*\in S$ because $x_{(1)}^*+x_{(2)}^*+x_{(3)}^*=0.8+0.8+0.4=2$. But $\sum_i x_i^*=2.4>2$, so $x^*\notin K=\operatorname{conv}(S_0)\supseteq SC(S_0)$. Thus $x^*\in IN^{(1)}_{\mathrm{sub}}(P;\{r-2\})\setminus SC(S_0)$, contradicting the assumed equality. Therefore, for this laminar instance, the split closure is strictly contained in the rank-1 Lovász–Newton submodular closure, as claimed.
\end{proof}

statement:
There exists a family of degree-3 multilinear polynomials {h_n} such that, for every fixed r ∈ ℕ, if we set κ_n := ⌊n/3⌋ and
P_n := { x ∈ [0,1]^n : ∑_{i=1}^n x_i ≤ κ_n − r },
then for all sufficiently large n we have

P_n ⊊ proj_x(SA(r) applied to h_n(x) ≥ 0).

In fact, for any fixed δ ∈ (0, 1/6), the right-hand side contains the point λ·1 with λ = κ_n/n + δ, so its coordinate sum is at least κ_n + δ n.
proof_markdown:
Fix r ∈ ℕ. Let κ_n := ⌊n/3⌋. Choose any constant ε ∈ (0,1) and define the degree-3 multilinear polynomial
$$
 h_n(x)
 :=
 \,\kappa_n - \sum_{i=1}^n x_i \, + \, \varepsilon\sum_{\substack{i,j,k\in[n]\\\text{all distinct}}} x_i\,(1-x_j)\,(1-x_k).
$$
We show that for all sufficiently large n, the knapsack polyhedron
$$
 P_n := \{x\in[0,1]^n : \sum_{i=1}^n x_i \le \kappa_n - r\}
$$
is strictly contained in the SA(r) projection for the constraint $h_n(x)\ge 0$.

Step 1 (Existence of an SA(r)-feasible point with large sum). Pick any fixed $\delta\in(0,\tfrac16)$ and set $\lambda = \kappa_n/n + \delta$. For all sufficiently large n, $\lambda\in[\tfrac13,\tfrac12]$. Consider the SA(r) moment assignment induced by the product distribution $X\sim \mathrm{Ber}(\lambda)^n$: for disjoint $S,T\subseteq[n]$ with $|S|+|T|\le r$, set
$$
 y_{S,T} := \mathbb{E}\Big[\prod_{i\in S}X_i\prod_{j\in T}(1-X_j)\Big] = \lambda^{|S|}(1-\lambda)^{|T|}.
$$
These moments satisfy SA(r) consistency. For any monomial multiplier $m(x)=\prod_{i\in S}x_i\prod_{j\in T}(1-x_j)$ with $|S|+|T|\le r$, independence and multilinearity give
$$
 \mathbb{E}[m(X)\,h_n(X)] = \mathbb{E}[m(X)]\Big(\kappa_n - \sum_{i=1}^n\mathbb{E}[X_i\mid m] + \varepsilon\sum_{\substack{i,j,k\ \text{distinct}}}\mathbb{E}[X_i(1-X_j)(1-X_k)\mid m]\Big).
$$
We bound the bracket uniformly in $m$. For the linear part, $\mathbb{E}[X_i\mid m]=1$ for $i\in S$, $0$ for $i\in T$, and $\lambda$ otherwise, hence
$$
 \sum_{i=1}^n\mathbb{E}[X_i\mid m] \le |S| + (n-|S|-|T|)\lambda \le n\lambda + r.
$$
For the cubic part, restricting to triples outside $S\cup T$ gives a lower bound, and for such $i,j,k$,
$\mathbb{E}[X_i(1-X_j)(1-X_k)\mid m]=\lambda(1-\lambda)^2$. The number of ordered distinct triples outside $S\cup T$ is at least $(n-r-2)^3$. Therefore
$$
 \sum_{\substack{i,j,k\ \text{distinct}}}\mathbb{E}[X_i(1-X_j)(1-X_k)\mid m]\ \ge\ (n-r-2)^3\,\lambda(1-\lambda)^2.
$$
Using $\lambda(1-\lambda)^2\ge \tfrac18$ on $[\tfrac13,\tfrac12]$ and $\kappa_n-n\lambda = -n\delta$, we obtain
$$
 \kappa_n-(n\lambda+r)+\varepsilon (n-r-2)^3\,\lambda(1-\lambda)^2\ \ge\ -n\delta - r + \tfrac{\varepsilon}{8}(n-r-2)^3\ >\ 0
$$
for all sufficiently large n (depending on $r,\varepsilon,\delta$). Thus $\mathbb{E}[m(X)h_n(X)]\ge 0$ for every admissible $m$, proving SA(r)-feasibility. The projected point is $\bar x:=\mathbb{E}[X]=\lambda\,\mathbf{1}$ with
$$
 \sum_{i=1}^n \bar x_i = n\lambda = \kappa_n + n\delta\ >\ \kappa_n.
$$

Step 2 (Every $x\in P_n$ is SA(r)-feasible). Fix any $x\in P_n$ and define the SA(r) moments by the product rule $y_{S,T}:=\prod_{i\in S}x_i\prod_{j\in T}(1-x_j)$ for all disjoint $S,T$ with $|S|{+}|T|\le r$. For $m(x)=\prod_{i\in S}x_i\prod_{j\in T}(1-x_j)$, multilinearity yields
$$
 \mathbb{E}[m(X)\,h_n(X)] = \mathbb{E}[m(X)]\Big(\kappa_n - \sum_{i=1}^n\mathbb{E}[X_i\mid m] + \varepsilon\sum_{\substack{i,j,k\ \text{distinct}}}\mathbb{E}[X_i(1-X_j)(1-X_k)\mid m]\Big),
$$
where now $\mathbb{E}[X_i\mid m]=1$ for $i\in S$, $0$ for $i\in T$, and $x_i$ otherwise. Hence
$$
 \sum_{i=1}^n\mathbb{E}[X_i\mid m] = |S| + \sum_{i\notin S\cup T} x_i \le |S| + \sum_{i=1}^n x_i \le r + (\kappa_n - r) = \kappa_n,
$$
while each cubic conditional expectation is nonnegative. Therefore $\mathbb{E}[m(X)h_n(X)]\ge 0$ for all $|S|{+}|T|\le r$, proving $x\in \operatorname{proj}_x(\mathrm{SA}(r)\text{ applied to }h_n\ge 0)$ and hence $P_n\subseteq \operatorname{proj}_x(\mathrm{SA}(r)\text{ applied to }h_n\ge 0)$.

Conclusion. By Step 1, the SA(r) projection contains $\bar x=\lambda\mathbf{1}$ with $\sum_i \bar x_i = \kappa_n + n\delta > \kappa_n \ge \kappa_n - r$, so $\bar x\notin P_n$. Combined with Step 2, this yields the strict containment
$$
 P_n\ \subsetneq\ \operatorname{proj}_x\big(\mathrm{SA}(r)\text{ applied to }h_n\ge 0\big)
$$
for all sufficiently large n (depending on $r,\varepsilon,\delta$). ∎

statement:
There exist a submodular function $f$, a polyhedron $P_0$, and a facet $H:\\;\pi^{\top}u\ge\beta$ of $C:=\operatorname{epi}(\widehat f)$ such that:

1) $H$ has infinite split rank with respect to every polyhedron $P$ satisfying $P\supseteq P_0$; and

2) there exists a neighborhood $\mathcal N\ni P_0$ such that, for every $P\in\mathcal N$, $H$ is valid for the one‑round submodular epigraph closure $IN^{(1)}_{\mathrm{sub}}(P;\{f\})$. In fact, $\mathcal N$ can be chosen as the family of right‑hand side perturbations $P(b')$ with $b'_F=q_F$ and $M_j z_{I^K}(q)\le b'_j$ for all $j\in J$ and all $K$ in a finite index set $\mathcal L$ arising from a Farkas certificate (hence $\mathcal N$ contains the one‑sided slab $\{b': b'_F=q_F,\ b'_J\in[\,q_J,\,q_J+\varepsilon\mathbf 1\,)\}$).
proof_markdown:
Proof. By the existence result “Infinite split rank vs. submodular epigraph cut strength,” there exist a submodular $f$, a polyhedron $P_0$, and a facet $H:\ \pi^{\top}u\ge\beta$ of $C:=\operatorname{epi}(\widehat f)$ such that: (i) $H$ has infinite split rank with respect to $P_0$, and (ii) $H$ is valid for the rank‑1 submodular epigraph closure $IN_{\mathrm{sub}}^{(1)}(P_0;\{f\})$.

Fix an $H$‑representation $P_0=\{u\in\mathbb{R}^{n+1}:Mu\le q\}$, where $M$ has finitely many rows. For any right‑hand side $b'$, denote $P(b'):=\{u:Mu\le b'\}$.

Definition (corner cones and the rank‑1 closure). Let $\mathcal I$ be the family of all basic index sets $I\subseteq[\mathrm{rows}(M)]$ of size $n+1$ with $\det M_I\neq0$. For $b'$, define the apex $z_I(b'):=M_I^{-1}b'_I$ and the corner cone
$$
K_I(b')\;:=\;\{u\in\mathbb{R}^{n+1}: M_Iu\le b'_I\}.
$$
Let
$$
\mathcal K(b')\;:=\;\{K_I(b'): I\in\mathcal I,\ z_I(b')\in P(b')\cap\operatorname{int}(C)\}.
$$
For each $K\in\mathcal K(b')$, the Balas intersection cut from $(K,C)$ is the valid inequality $H_K^+:\;\pi_K^{\top}u\ge\beta_K$ obtained via the standard formula. Define the specialized rank‑1 closure
$$
IN_{\mathrm{sub}}^{(1)}(P(b');\{f\})\;:=\;P(b')\cap\bigcap_{K\in\mathcal K(b')} H_K^+.
$$
As $\mathcal I$ is finite, so is $\mathcal K(b')$.

Since $H$ is valid for $IN_{\mathrm{sub}}^{(1)}(P_0;\{f\})$, the polyhedron
$$
X_0\;:=\;\Bigl\{u: Mu\le q,\ \pi_K^{\top}u\ge\beta_K\ \forall K\in\mathcal K(q)\Bigr\}
$$
satisfies $X_0\subseteq H^+$. By Farkas’ lemma (finiteness of $\mathcal K(q)$), there exist nonnegative multipliers $\alpha\in\mathbb{R}_+^{\mathrm{rows}(M)}$ and $\mu\in\mathbb{R}_+^{\mathcal K(q)}$ such that
$$
\pi\;=\;\sum_{K\in\mathcal K(q)} \mu_K\,\pi_K\ -\ M^{\top}\alpha,\qquad
\beta\;\le\;\sum_{K\in\mathcal K(q)} \mu_K\,\beta_K\ -\ q^{\top}\alpha.
$$
Let $\mathcal L:=\{K\in\mathcal K(q):\ \mu_K>0\}$ (finite) and $R:=\operatorname{supp}(\alpha)\subseteq[\mathrm{rows}(M)]$. For $K\in\mathcal L$ write $I^K$ for its basic index set and define
$$
F\;:=\;R\ \cup\ \bigcup_{K\in\mathcal L} I^K,\qquad J:= [\mathrm{rows}(M)]\setminus F.
$$
Define the neighborhood
$$
\mathcal N\;:=\;\Bigl\{P(b'):\ b'_F=q_F,\ \ b'_j\ge\max_{K\in\mathcal L} M_j z_{I^K}(q)\ \forall j\in J\Bigr\}.
$$
Note that $P_0=P(q)\in\mathcal N$. Moreover, for every $P(b')\in\mathcal N$ and each $K\in\mathcal L$ we have $b'_{I^K}=q_{I^K}$, so
$$
z_{I^K}(b')=M_{I^K}^{-1}b'_{I^K}=M_{I^K}^{-1}q_{I^K}=z_{I^K}(q),
$$
and hence the cone $K$ (and its cut $H_K^+$) is unchanged on $\mathcal N$. Because $z_{I^K}(q)\in\operatorname{int}(C)$ and, by the definition of $\mathcal N$, $M_j z_{I^K}(q)\le b'_j$ for all $j\in J$, we have $z_{I^K}(b')\in P(b')\cap\operatorname{int}(C)$. Thus $K\in\mathcal K(b')$ for all $K\in\mathcal L$ and all $P(b')\in\mathcal N$.

Validity in one round on $\mathcal N$. Fix $P=P(b')\in\mathcal N$ and let $u\in IN_{\mathrm{sub}}^{(1)}(P;\{f\})$. Then $Mu\le b'$ and $\pi_K^{\top}u\ge\beta_K$ for all $K\in\mathcal K(b')$, in particular for all $K\in\mathcal L$. Using the certificate and that $\alpha_j=0$ for $j\in J$ while $b'_F=q_F$, we obtain
$$
\pi^{\top}u\;=\;\Bigl(\sum_{K\in\mathcal L}\mu_K\,\pi_K\ -\ M^{\top}\alpha\Bigr)^{\!\top}u
\;\ge\;\sum_{K\in\mathcal L}\mu_K\,\beta_K\ -\ b'^{\top}\alpha
\;=\;\sum_{K\in\mathcal L}\mu_K\,\beta_K\ -\ q^{\top}\alpha
\;\ge\;\beta.
$$
Thus $H$ is valid for $IN_{\mathrm{sub}}^{(1)}(P;\{f\})$ for all $P\in\mathcal N$.

Persistence of infinite split rank for all supersets of $P_0$. Let $SC^r(\cdot)$ denote the $r$‑round split closure. Monotonicity gives $Q_1\subseteq Q_2\Rightarrow SC^r(Q_1)\subseteq SC^r(Q_2)$ for all $r\in\mathbb{N}$. Hence for any polyhedron $P\supseteq P_0$, we have $SC^r(P_0)\subseteq SC^r(P)$ for all $r$. Because $H$ is violated by $SC^r(P_0)$ for every finite $r$ (by the existence result), it is violated by $SC^r(P)$ for every finite $r$ as well. Therefore $H$ has infinite split rank with respect to every $P\supseteq P_0$.

Combining both parts, there exist $f$, $P_0$, and a facet $H$ of $\operatorname{epi}(\widehat f)$ such that (i) $H$ has infinite split rank with respect to all $P\supseteq P_0$, and (ii) there is a neighborhood $\mathcal N\ni P_0$ (as above) for which $H$ is valid for $IN^{(1)}_{\mathrm{sub}}(P;\{f\})$ for every $P\in\mathcal N$. $\square$

statement:
There exists a degree-3 multilinear family h_n such that, writing P_n := {x ∈ [0,1]^n : ∑_{i=1}^n x_i ≤ ⌊n/3⌋ − r} for any fixed integer r ≥ 0, we have for every n ≥ 3 and every Sherali–Adams level k ∈ {0,1,…,n}:

IN^{(1)}_{\mathrm{sub}}(\{(x,t) : t ≥ h_n(x)\} ∩ (P_n × \mathbb{R}); \{h_n\}) \subsetneq \operatorname{proj}_x(\mathrm{SA}(k) \text{ applied to } \{0 ≤ x ≤ 1,\ h_n(x) ≥ 0\}) = [0,1]^n.

In particular, the strict separation holds at every SA level.
proof_markdown:
\begin{proof}
Fix any integer $r \ge 0$ and $n \ge 3$. Let $\kappa_n := \lfloor n/3\rfloor$ and
\[
P_n := \Bigl\{x \in [0,1]^n : \sum_{i=1}^n x_i \le \kappa_n - r\Bigr\}.
\]
Define the symmetric degree-3 multilinear polynomial
\[
 h_n(x) := C_n - \sum_{1\le i<j\le n} x_i x_j - \sum_{1\le i<j<k\le n} x_i x_j x_k,
\]
with $C_n := \binom{n}{2}+\binom{n}{3}+1$. Writing $s(x):=\sum_{i=1}^n x_i$, the identity on $\{0,1\}^n$ gives
\[
 h_n(x)= C_n - \binom{s(x)}{2} - \binom{s(x)}{3}.
\]
We record two facts.

(1) $h_n$ is submodular. For any symmetric set function of the form $f(s)=a_0+a_1 s+a_2\binom{s}{2}+a_3\binom{s}{3}$ we have $\Delta^2 f(s)=a_2+a_3 s$. Here $a_2=a_3=-1$, hence $\Delta^2 h_n(s)=-1-s\le 0$ for all $s\in\{0,\dots,n-2\}$, which is equivalent to submodularity.

(2) $h_n\ge 1$ on $[0,1]^n$. Since $x_i x_j\le 1$ and $x_i x_j x_k\le 1$ for all $x\in[0,1]^n$,
\[
 h_n(x)\ge C_n-\binom{n}{2}-\binom{n}{3}=1.
\]
Consequently $h_n(x)\ge 0$ holds throughout $[0,1]^n$.

Consider the one-round submodular-epigraph closure over
\[
S_n:=\{(x,t):\ x\in P_n,\ t\ge h_n(x)\}
\]
using the family $\{h_n\}$, i.e., $IN^{(1)}_{\mathrm{sub}}(S_n;\{h_n\})$. By construction this closure is obtained by intersecting $S_n$ with additional valid inequalities, hence it is a subset of $S_n$. Therefore
\[
 \operatorname{proj}_x\bigl(IN^{(1)}_{\mathrm{sub}}(S_n;\{h_n\})\bigr)\subseteq \operatorname{proj}_x(S_n)=P_n.
\]

We now compare with Sherali–Adams. Apply $\mathrm{SA}(k)$ to the system $0\le x\le 1$ and $h_n(x)\ge 0$, and project to $x$-space. Because $h_n(x)\ge 0$ for every $x\in[0,1]^n$, taking the canonical moment assignment $y_S:=\prod_{i\in S}x_i$ satisfies all SA linearizations of the box $[0,1]^n$ and all lifted inequalities obtained by multiplying $h_n(x)\ge 0$ with any SA multiplier $\prod_{i\in A}x_i\prod_{j\in B}(1-x_j)$. Thus, for every level $k\in\{0,1,\dots,n\}$,
\[
 \operatorname{proj}_x\bigl(\mathrm{SA}(k) \text{ applied to } \{0\le x\le 1,\ h_n(x)\ge 0\}\bigr)=[0,1]^n.
\]

To witness strictness, take $x^*:=\tfrac{1}{2}\mathbf 1\in[0,1]^n$. Then
\[
 \sum_{i=1}^n x^*_i = \frac{n}{2} > \frac{n}{3} \ge \lfloor n/3\rfloor \ge \lfloor n/3\rfloor - r,
\]
so $x^*\notin P_n$. Consequently,
\[
 \operatorname{proj}_x\bigl(IN^{(1)}_{\mathrm{sub}}(S_n;\{h_n\})\bigr)\subseteq P_n\subsetneq [0,1]^n
 = \operatorname{proj}_x\bigl(\mathrm{SA}(k) \text{ applied to } \{0\le x\le 1,\ h_n(x)\ge 0\}\bigr)
\]
for every $k\in\{0,1,\dots,n\}$. Hence the strict separation holds at every SA level.
\end{proof}

statement:
For every n and every multilinear polynomial of the form
$$ h_n(x)=\sum_{S\subseteq[n],\ |S|\ge3} c_S\,x_S,\qquad c_S\ge0, $$
with $P_n:=\{x\in[0,1]^n:\ x([n])\le2\}$, we have for all $k\in\{0,\dots,n\}$:
$$ \operatorname{proj}_x\, \mathrm{SA}(k)\bigl( \{ (x,t): 0\le x\le1,\ t\ge h_n(x)\}\bigr) = [0,1]^n, $$
while
$$ IN^{(1)}_{\mathrm{sub}}\bigl( P_n\times\mathbb R;\{h_n\}\bigr) = P_n\times[0,\infty)= \operatorname{conv}\bigl( (P_n\times\mathbb R)\cap\{ (x,t): x\in\{0,1\}^n,\ t\ge h_n(x)\}\bigr). $$
proof_markdown:
Proof. Fix $n\in\mathbb N$ and let
$$ h_n(x)=\sum_{S\subseteq[n],\ |S|\ge3} c_S\,x_S \quad (c_S\ge0), $$
with maximum degree $d:=\max\{|S|: c_S\ne0\}\ge3$, and set
$$ P_n:=\{x\in[0,1]^n:\ x([n])\le2\}. $$
Note that for every $A\subseteq[n]$ with $|A|\le2$ we have $h_n(\mathbf 1_A)=0$ (every monomial has degree at least $3$) and $h_n(x)\ge0$ for all $x\in[0,1]^n$ (coefficients are nonnegative).

We prove the two assertions.

1) SA projection is the trivial box for all levels. Consider the epigraph
$$ U_n:=\{(x,t): 0\le x\le1,\ t\ge h_n(x)\}. $$
Fix $k\in\{0,\dots,n\}$ and an arbitrary $\bar x\in[0,1]^n$. Define a product distribution $X=(X_1,\dots,X_n)$ with independent $X_i\sim \mathrm{Bernoulli}(\bar x_i)$ and set $T:=h_n(X)$. For every $S\subseteq[n]$ define
$$ y_S:=\mathbb E\Bigl[\prod_{i\in S}X_i\Bigr]=\prod_{i\in S}\bar x_i \quad (|S|\le k+d),\qquad z_S:=\mathbb E\Bigl[T\prod_{i\in S}X_i\Bigr]\quad (|S|\le k), $$
and set $t:=z_\emptyset=\mathbb E[T]$. Interpret $y_S$ as the linearization variable for $x_S$ and $z_S$ for $x_S t$.

Claim: The assignment $\{y_S,z_S,t\}$ satisfies every inequality in $\mathrm{SA}(k)(U_n)$.

Proof of the claim. Every SA inequality is obtained by taking a base inequality $g(x,t)\in\{x_i\ge0,\ 1-x_i\ge0,\ t-h_n(x)\ge0\}$, multiplying by $R(x)=\prod_{i\in S} r_i(x)$ with $r_i\in\{x_i,1-x_i\}$ and $|S|\le k$, expanding and reducing via $x_i^2=x_i$ (so all monomials are square-free), and linearizing by replacing $x_S$ (resp. $x_S t$) with $y_S$ (resp. $z_S$). For $X\in\{0,1\}^n$ we have pointwise $R(X)\in\{0,1\}$ and $g(X,T)\ge0$; in particular, for $g=t-h_n(x)$ we have $T-h_n(X)\equiv0$. Since $X_i^2=X_i$ for $0$–$1$ variables, the reduced polynomial equals $R(X)g(X,T)$. Taking expectations gives
$$ \mathbb E\bigl[R(X)g(X,T)\bigr]\ge0,\qquad \mathbb E\Bigl[\prod_{i\in S}X_i\Bigr]=y_S,\qquad \mathbb E\Bigl[T\prod_{i\in S}X_i\Bigr]=z_S. $$
Thus each linearized inequality holds at $\{y_S,z_S,t\}$, proving the claim.

Therefore, for every $\bar x\in[0,1]^n$ there exists a feasible lift in $\mathrm{SA}(k)(U_n)$ projecting to $\bar x$. Since all SA relaxations retain $0\le x\le1$, we conclude
$$ \operatorname{proj}_x\,\mathrm{SA}(k)\bigl(\{(x,t):0\le x\le1,\ t\ge h_n(x)\}\bigr)=[0,1]^n\quad\forall k\in\{0,\dots,n\}. $$

2) Rank-1 submodular epigraph cuts recover the exact binary convex hull over $P_n$. Consider
$$ \mathcal S_n:=(P_n\times\mathbb R)\cap\{(x,t): x\in\{0,1\}^n,\ t\ge h_n(x)\}. $$
Because $x([n])\le2$ forces at most two ones overall, every monomial of degree at least $3$ vanishes on $P_n\cap\{0,1\}^n$, hence $h_n(x)=0$ there and
$$ \mathcal S_n=\{(\mathbf 1_A,t):\ |A|\le2,\ t\ge0\}. $$
It follows that
$$ \operatorname{conv}(\mathcal S_n)=\operatorname{conv}\{\mathbf 1_A:\ |A|\le2\}\times[0,\infty)=P_n\times[0,\infty), $$
using the integrality of the uniform matroid polytope $\{x\in[0,1]^n:\ x([n])\le2\}$.

We now prove
$$ IN^{(1)}_{\mathrm{sub}}\bigl(P_n\times\mathbb R;\{h_n\}\bigr)=P_n\times[0,\infty)=\operatorname{conv}(\mathcal S_n). $$
The inclusion $\operatorname{conv}(\mathcal S_n)\subseteq IN^{(1)}_{\mathrm{sub}}(P_n\times\mathbb R;\{h_n\})$ is immediate since every rank-1 submodular epigraph intersection cut is valid for $\mathcal S_n$.

For the reverse inclusion, set $f:=-h_n$. For each $S$ with $|S|\ge3$, the set function $A\mapsto \mathbf 1_{\{S\subseteq A\}}$ is supermodular, hence $-\mathbf 1_{\{S\subseteq A\}}$ is submodular; by nonnegativity of the coefficients, $f$ is a nonnegative linear combination of submodular functions and is therefore submodular. It is normalized ($f(\emptyset)=0$). By the Lov\'asz-extension fact, $\widehat f$ is convex and
$$ \operatorname{epi}(\widehat f)=\operatorname{conv}\{(\mathbf 1_A,\tau):\tau\ge f(A)\}. $$
Passing to $(x,t)$ via $\tau=-t$, the closed convex set
$$ T:=\{(x,t): -t\ge \widehat f(x)\} $$
is $\mathcal S$-free for $\mathcal S:=\{(x,t): x\in\{0,1\}^n,\ t\ge h_n(x)\}$, because for $x=\mathbf 1_A$ we have $-t\ge\widehat f(\mathbf 1_A)=f(A)=-h_n(\mathbf 1_A)$ iff $t\le h_n(\mathbf 1_A)$. Moreover $\widehat f\le0$ on $[0,1]^n$ (since $f(\mathbf 1_A)\le0$ for all $A$ and $\widehat f$ is the convex closure on $[0,1]^n$), so every $(\bar x,\bar t)$ with $\bar t<0$ lies in $\mathrm{int}(T)$. By standard $\mathcal S$-free intersection-cut results, from $T$ one obtains a valid rank-1 intersection cut separating any point $z\notin\operatorname{conv}(\mathcal S)$; in particular, every $(\bar x,\bar t)\in P_n\times\mathbb R$ with $\bar t<0$ is cut off. Consequently,
$$ IN^{(1)}_{\mathrm{sub}}(P_n\times\mathbb R;\{h_n\})\ \subseteq\ \{(x,t): x\in P_n,\ t\ge0\}=P_n\times[0,\infty). $$
Combining both inclusions yields
$$ IN^{(1)}_{\mathrm{sub}}(P_n\times\mathbb R;\{h_n\})=P_n\times[0,\infty)=\operatorname{conv}(\mathcal S_n). $$

Putting 1) and 2) together proves the claim for the stated class of $h_n$ and for every $k\in\{0,\dots,n\}$. ∎

statement:
Impossibility of a one-auxiliary s–t cut lift for a positive cubic monomial. For every $\gamma>0$, there is no quadratic pseudo-Boolean function $Q(x_1,x_2,x_3,y)$, representable by a single $s$–$t$ cut (equivalently, with all pairwise coefficients nonpositive), such that for all $x\in\{0,1\}^3$,
$$
\gamma\,x_1x_2x_3=\min_{y\in\{0,1\}} Q(x,y).
$$
Consequently, a scheme that uses one auxiliary node per positive "frustrated" triangle cannot, in general, provide an exact $s$–$t$ cut lift.
proof_markdown:
\begin{proof}
Fix any $\gamma>0$ and assume, for contradiction, that there exists a single-auxiliary $s$--$t$ cut gadget providing an exact lift of the positive cubic monomial, i.e., a quadratic pseudo--Boolean energy $Q(x_1,x_2,x_3,y)$ representable by one $s$--$t$ cut such that
$$
\gamma\,x_1x_2x_3=\min_{y\in\{0,1\}} Q(x,y)\qquad\forall x\in\{0,1\}^3.
$$

By the Kolmogorov--Zabih characterization, $Q$ can be written in the canonical quadratic form
$$
Q(x,y)=c+\sum_{i=1}^3 a_i x_i+a_y y+\sum_{1\le i<j\le 3} b_{ij}x_ix_j+\sum_{i=1}^3 b_{iy} x_i y,
$$
with the (cut-representability) constraints $b_{ij}\le 0$ and $b_{iy}\le 0$ for all $i,j$. Eliminating $y\in\{0,1\}$ gives
$$
\min_{y\in\{0,1\}} Q(x,y)= c+\sum_{i=1}^3 a_i x_i+\sum_{1\le i<j\le 3} b_{ij}x_ix_j+\min\bigl\{0,\ a_y+\sum_{i=1}^3 b_{iy}x_i\bigr\}.
$$
Set $f(x):=\min_y Q(x,y)$ and write the last term as $\phi(x):=\min\{0,\alpha+\sum_{i=1}^3 p_i x_i\}$ with $\alpha:=a_y$ and $p_i:=b_{iy}\le0$. Thus
$$
 f(x)=c+\sum_{i=1}^3 a_i x_i+\sum_{i<j} b_{ij}x_ix_j+\phi(x).
$$
By construction, $\phi\le 0$ pointwise and is the minimum of two modular functions; equivalently, if we set $w_i:=-p_i\ge0$ and $\mu:=-\alpha$, then $-\phi(A)=[\,\mu+\sum_{i\in A} w_i\,]_+$ for $A\subseteq\{1,2,3\}$.

Since $\gamma x_1x_2x_3$ vanishes at $x=0$, at the unit vectors $e_i$, and at $e_i+e_j$ for $i\ne j$, matching $f\equiv \gamma x_1x_2x_3$ on these seven points forces
$$
\begin{aligned}
&c=-\phi(\emptyset),\\
&a_i=\phi(\emptyset)-\phi(\{i\}),\quad i=1,2,3,\\
&b_{ij}=\phi(\{i\})+\phi(\{j\})-\phi(\emptyset)-\phi(\{i,j\})= -\,\Delta_{ij}\phi(\emptyset),\quad 1\le i<j\le 3,
\end{aligned}
$$
where $\Delta_{ij}\phi(A):=\phi(A\cup\{i,j\})-\phi(A\cup\{i\})-\phi(A\cup\{j\})+\phi(A)$ is the discrete second difference. The cut-representability constraint $b_{ij}\le0$ therefore yields
$$
\Delta_{ij}\phi(\emptyset)\ \ge\ 0\qquad\text{for all }1\le i<j\le3.\tag{1}
$$
On the other hand, $\phi$ is submodular: indeed, $-\phi(A)=[\,\mu+\sum_{i\in A} w_i\,]_+$ is the composition of the convex nondecreasing function $t\mapsto [t]_+$ with a modular set function, which is supermodular; hence $\phi$ is submodular, and so
$$
\Delta_{ij}\phi(A)\ \le\ 0\qquad\text{for all }A\subseteq\{1,2,3\},\ 1\le i<j\le3.\tag{2}
$$
Combining (1) and (2) at $A=\emptyset$ gives
$$
\Delta_{ij}\phi(\emptyset)=0\qquad\text{for }1\le i<j\le3.\tag{3}
$$
Now compute the cubic coefficient of $f$. Constants, linear, and quadratic terms vanish under the third discrete difference, hence
$$
\Delta_3\Delta_2\Delta_1 f(0)=\Delta_3\Delta_2\Delta_1\phi(0)=\Delta_3\bigl(\Delta_{12}\phi\bigr)(\emptyset)=\Delta_{12}\phi(\{3\})-\Delta_{12}\phi(\emptyset).
$$
By submodularity (2), $\Delta_{12}\phi(\{3\})\le0$, and by (3), $\Delta_{12}\phi(\emptyset)=0$. Therefore
$$
\Delta_3\Delta_2\Delta_1 f(0)\le 0.
$$
But $f\equiv \gamma x_1x_2x_3$ has third difference $\Delta_3\Delta_2\Delta_1 (\gamma x_1x_2x_3)(0)=\gamma>0$, a contradiction.

Thus no quadratic $s$--$t$ cut with a single auxiliary node can represent the positive cubic monomial exactly after projection, for any $\gamma>0$. \qedhere
\end{proof}

statement:
Non-tightness of the rank-1 submodular epigraph closure for any positive budget. For every n≥1, every integer k with 1≤k≤n, and every monotone submodular function f:2^{[n]}→ℝ that is not constant (equivalently, ∃i with f({i})>f(∅)), we have
\[
\max\{ f(x): x\in X_k\} \,>\, \min\{ t: (x,t)\in IN^{(1)}_{\mathrm{sub}}(P_k\times\mathbb{R};\{f\})\},
\]
where X_k:=\{x\in\{0,1\}^n: \sum_i x_i\le k\} and P_k:=\{x\in[0,1]^n: \sum_i x_i\le k\}.
proof_markdown:
Fix arbitrary n≥1, k with 1≤k≤n, and a monotone submodular f:2^{[n]}→ℝ that is not constant. By monotonicity and submodularity, there exists an index i with f({i})>f(∅): indeed, if f({i})=f(∅) for all i, submodularity gives f(A∪{i})−f(A)≤f({i})−f(∅)=0 for all A and i, while monotonicity forces all such marginals to be ≥0, hence all marginals are 0 and f is constant—a contradiction.

1) Validity of rank-1 epigraph cuts: Every rank-1 submodular epigraph intersection cut for f is valid for the integer epigraph
\[ \mathcal S_{\mathrm{epi}}:=\{(\mathbf{1}_A,t): A\subseteq[n],\ t\ge f(A)\}. \]
Therefore
\[ \mathcal S_{\mathrm{epi}}\cap(P_k\times\mathbb{R})\subseteq IN^{(1)}_{\mathrm{sub}}(P_k\times\mathbb{R};\{f\}). \]
Since \(\mathbf 0\in P_k\) and \((\mathbf 0, f(\emptyset))\in\mathcal S_{\mathrm{epi}}\), we obtain
\[ \min\{t:(x,t)\in IN^{(1)}_{\mathrm{sub}}(P_k\times\mathbb{R};\{f\})\}\ \le\ f(\emptyset). \]

2) Positive-budget maximization value: Because k≥1, the unit vector e_i belongs to X_k. Hence
\[ \max\{f(x):x\in X_k\}\ \ge\ f(e_i)=f(\{i\})\ >\ f(\emptyset). \]

Combining the two displays yields
\[ \min\{t:(x,t)\in IN^{(1)}_{\mathrm{sub}}(P_k\times\mathbb{R};\{f\})\}\ \le\ f(\emptyset)\ <\ \max\{f(x):x\in X_k\}, \]
which proves the claimed strict inequality for any positive budget k.

statement:
For every $\gamma>0$ and every number $m\ge 0$ of auxiliary binary variables, there is no submodular function $F:\{0,1\}^{3+m}\to\mathbb R$ such that
$$\gamma x_1x_2x_3=\min_{y\in\{0,1\}^m} F(x,y)\quad\text{for all }x\in\{0,1\}^3.$$
In particular, no single $s$–$t$ cut reduction (with any number of auxiliary binaries) can represent the positive cubic monomial $\gamma x_1x_2x_3$.
proof_markdown:
Suppose, for some $\gamma>0$ and some $m\ge 0$, there exists a submodular set function $F$ on $2^{X\cup Y}$, where $X=\{1,2,3\}$ indexes $x$ and $Y$ indexes $m$ auxiliary binaries, such that
$$\gamma x_1x_2x_3=\min_{B\subseteq Y} F(A\cup B)\quad\text{for all }A\subseteq X,$$
with $A$ identified with the support of $x$.

Define $g:2^X\to\mathbb R$ by $g(A):=\min_{B\subseteq Y} F(A\cup B)$. We claim $g$ is submodular. Indeed, for any $A,C\subseteq X$, choose minimizers $B_A,B_C\subseteq Y$ so that $g(A)=F(A\cup B_A)$ and $g(C)=F(C\cup B_C)$. By submodularity of $F$,
$$
F(A\cup B_A)+F(C\cup B_C)
\;\ge\; F\bigl((A\cup C)\cup(B_A\cup B_C)\bigr)+F\bigl((A\cap C)\cup(B_A\cap B_C)\bigr)
\;\ge\; g(A\cup C)+g(A\cap C).
$$
Hence $g$ is submodular.

By the assumed representation, $g(A)=\gamma\,\mathbf 1\{\{1,2,3\}\subseteq A\}$. This set function is not submodular when $\gamma>0$: taking $A=\{1,2\}$ and $C=\{2,3\}$ yields
$$g(A)+g(C)=0+0<\gamma+0=g(A\cup C)+g(A\cap C),$$
contradicting submodularity of $g$.

Therefore, no such submodular $F$ exists. In particular, since any single $s$–$t$ cut energy is submodular on all of its variables, no single $s$–$t$ cut reduction (regardless of the number of auxiliary binaries) can represent the positive cubic monomial $\gamma x_1x_2x_3$. ∎
